stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, can you explain the principles of mechanical ventilation and the different modes available?

prompts.text: What are the key variables in mechanical ventilation?
expectedKeyFacts: Tidal volume (Vt): typically 6-8 mL/kg ideal body weight
Respiratory rate (RR): typically 12-20 breaths/min
Inspiratory:Expiratory ratio (I:E): normally 1:2
PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure): typically 5-10 cmH₂O
FiO₂ (fraction of inspired oxygen): adjust to target SpO₂
Peak and plateau pressures
Minute ventilation = Vt × RR

prompts.text: Explain the difference between volume-controlled and pressure-controlled ventilation.
expectedKeyFacts: Volume-controlled (VCV): delivers set tidal volume, pressure varies
Guarantees minute ventilation
Risk of barotrauma if high pressures generated
Pressure-controlled (PCV): delivers set inspiratory pressure, volume varies
Pressure limit protects against barotrauma
Tidal volume varies with compliance
PCV may be better in non-compliant lungs (ARDS)
Both modes can be used with PEEP

prompts.text: What is PEEP and why is it used?
expectedKeyFacts: Positive end-expiratory pressure — prevents alveolar collapse
Maintains FRC above closing capacity
Improves oxygenation by recruiting collapsed alveoli
Reduces atelectrauma (repeated opening/closing injury)
Reduces shunt fraction
Typical PEEP 5-10 cmH₂O, higher in ARDS (10-15 cmH₂O)
Excessive PEEP can reduce venous return and cardiac output
PEEP also reduces work of breathing in COPD (intrinsic PEEP)

prompts.text: A patient with ARDS is hypoxic despite high FiO₂. How would you optimise their ventilation?
expectedKeyFacts: Lung protective strategy: low tidal volume (6 mL/kg IBW), limit plateau pressure <30 cmH₂O
Increase PEEP to recruit alveoli — balance oxygenation vs cardiovascular effects
Prone positioning — improves V/Q matching, reduces mortality in severe ARDS
Recruitment manoeuvres (cautiously)
Consider permissive hypercapnia if pH >7.2
Neuromuscular blockade in severe ARDS (first 48 hours)
ECMO if refractory hypoxaemia despite maximal support
Avoid excessive oxygen — target SpO₂ 88-92%

prompts.text: What is volutrauma and how is it different from barotrauma?
expectedKeyFacts: Barotrauma: physical injury from high airway pressures (pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum)
Volutrauma: alveolar damage from overdistension — more important mechanism in ARDS
Even 'normal' pressures can cause volutrauma if volume too large
Biotrauma: inflammatory cascade from mechanical ventilation
Atelectrauma: repeated opening/closing of alveoli
Lung protective ventilation minimises these injuries
Focus on plateau pressure and tidal volume, not just peak pressure
Driving pressure (plateau - PEEP) correlates with mortality

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about lung protective ventilation in ARDS — what are the key principles?
keyFacts: Tidal volume, RR, PEEP, FiO₂, I:E ratio
PEEP prevents alveolar collapse, improves oxygenation
Lung protective: 6 mL/kg IBW, plateau <30 cmH₂O
ARDS: high PEEP, prone positioning, permissive hypercapnia

scoringGuidance.pass: Describes key ventilator variables, distinguishes VCV from PCV, explains PEEP mechanism and benefits, knows lung protective strategy for ARDS, differentiates volutrauma from barotrauma; stronger candidates discuss driving pressure and prone positioning evidence
scoringGuidance.borderline: Knows basic ventilator settings but unclear on modes, mentions PEEP but mechanism vague, aware of ARDS but protective strategy incomplete
scoringGuidance.fail: Cannot describe ventilator variables, does not understand VCV vs PCV, unaware of PEEP benefits, no knowledge of lung protective ventilation or volutrauma
